texts.orig: /2014/05/20/switching-to-systemd-on-debian-jessie/
texts.text: /2014/05/20/switching-to-systemd-on-debian-jessie/

texts.orig: command line
texts.text: command line

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: debian
texts.text: debian

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: fedora

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: systemd
texts.text: systemd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It seems like everyone is embracing systemd these days. It's been in Fedora since 2011 and it's already in the RHEL 7 release candidate. Arch Linux and Gentoo have it as well. Debian got on board with the jessie release (which is currently in testing).
texts.text: It seems like everyone is embracing systemd these days. It's been in Fedora since 2011 and it's already in the RHEL 7 release candidate. Arch Linux and Gentoo have it as well. Debian got on board with the jessie release (which is currently in testing).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Switching from old SysVinit to systemd in Debian jessie is quite simple. For the extremely cautious system administrators, you can  follow Debian's guide and test systemd  before you make the full cutover.
texts.text: Switching from old SysVinit to systemd in Debian jessie is quite simple. For the extremely cautious system administrators, you can  follow Debian's guide and test systemd  before you make the full cutover.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, I've had great results with making the jump in one pass:
texts.text: However, I've had great results with making the jump in one pass:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
apt-get update
apt-get install systemd systemd-sysv
reboot
texts.text:
apt-get update
apt-get install systemd systemd-sysv
reboot

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After you reboot, you might notice
texts.text: After you reboot, you might notice

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /sbin/init
texts.text: /sbin/init

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: still hanging out in your process list:
texts.text: still hanging out in your process list:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ps aufx | grep init
root         1  0.0  0.1  45808  3820 ?        Ss   08:16   0:00 /sbin/init
texts.text:
# ps aufx | grep init
root         1  0.0  0.1  45808  3820 ?        Ss   08:16   0:00 /sbin/init

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That's actually a symlink to systemd:
texts.text: That's actually a symlink to systemd:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ls -al /sbin/init
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 20 Mar 19 13:15 /sbin/init -> /lib/systemd/systemd
texts.text:
# ls -al /sbin/init
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 20 Mar 19 13:15 /sbin/init -> /lib/systemd/systemd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You also have journald for quick access to logs:
texts.text: You also have journald for quick access to logs:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# journalctl -u cron
-- Logs begin at Tue 2014-05-20 08:16:21 CDT, end at Tue 2014-05-20 08:31:20 CDT. --
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 /usr/sbin/cron[837]: (CRON) INFO (pidfile fd = 3)
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 cron[774]: Starting periodic command scheduler: cron.
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 systemd[1]: Started LSB: Regular background program processing daemon.
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 /usr/sbin/cron[842]: (CRON) STARTUP (fork ok)
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 /usr/sbin/cron[842]: (CRON) INFO (Running @reboot jobs)
May 20 08:17:01 jessie-auditd-2 CRON[990]: pam_unix(cron:session): session opened for user root by (uid=0)
May 20 08:17:01 jessie-auditd-2 /USR/SBIN/CRON[991]: (root) CMD (   cd / && run-parts --report /etc/cron.hourly)
texts.text:
# journalctl -u cron
-- Logs begin at Tue 2014-05-20 08:16:21 CDT, end at Tue 2014-05-20 08:31:20 CDT. --
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 /usr/sbin/cron[837]: (CRON) INFO (pidfile fd = 3)
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 cron[774]: Starting periodic command scheduler: cron.
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 systemd[1]: Started LSB: Regular background program processing daemon.
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 /usr/sbin/cron[842]: (CRON) STARTUP (fork ok)
May 20 08:16:24 jessie-auditd-2 /usr/sbin/cron[842]: (CRON) INFO (Running @reboot jobs)
May 20 08:17:01 jessie-auditd-2 CRON[990]: pam_unix(cron:session): session opened for user root by (uid=0)
May 20 08:17:01 jessie-auditd-2 /USR/SBIN/CRON[991]: (root) CMD (   cd / && run-parts --report /etc/cron.hourly)
